Of Chinard's Edition Of Diary

Two types of awards for Omicron
Delta Kappa, honorary activities fraternity, were presented at yesterday's
assembly when James Butcher, a
senior, and Clarence Weimer, Mead
Johnson, and Leonard Emmert, juniors were tapped by President T.
Bayard Williams, Jr.; and Dr. John
C. French, second national president,
was given a past president's Key by
William Mofeley Brown, executive
secretary of the national fraternity.
Preceding the announcement of
the new selections by Richard Feise,
Williams outlined the principles upon
which the organization is based. He
stated:
"Most students fail to grasp the
idea that two of our primary requisites are scholarship and character.
Before we consider any case, the individual must have, as the NEWSLETTER put it, 'a respectable general
average.' We will continue to emphasize these two requirements in the
future."
Told Of Hopkins' Part
Mr. Brown told the audience of the
part played by the Hopkins chapter of
0. D. K., the second one established,
having followed Washington and Lee.
He congratulated those who were
just inducted and informed them of
the significance of the honor. Adding
that there was a special award for
past officers, Mr. Brown presented
Dr. French with a gold key.
"Being president of 0. D. K. from
1920-1922," the speaker declared,
"Dr. French was instrumental in the
great progress the organization attained. I am happy to honor such a
past leader of this fraternity."
Dean Berry Comments
When called upon to address the
assembly, Dr. ?French recalled the
early days of the organization and
praised the recent progress which 0.
D. K. has made. He issued a warning
to the Hopkins Chapter not to be too
exclusive in their selection of new
members since the organization has
such an important position on the
campus.
Before the presentation of the 0.
D. K. awards, the freshman class
team which won the basketball championship were given charms.
William McClean, president of the
Student Council, introduced Dean
Edward W. Berry, whom he said
would "give the boys hell" about the
past Soph-Frosh Week.
"I can appreciate the feelings of
youth," Dean Berry stated, "yet I
think this past week which gave the
worst exhibition I've ever seen, went
too far. Such demonstrations do Hopkins no end of harm. The present
freshmen who will be sophomores
next year should bear this past experience in mind and take the lead
next year in toning down such activities."
After the regular assembly, five
freshmein Were nominated for the
Student Council. They were:
JAMES LYLE
EVERETT GAUNT
DONALD EMERSON
MARTIN SIMENSKY
ROBERT STEVENS
Primaries will be today and general elections on Monday.

Kouwenhoven Speaks
Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven, professor of electrical engineering and
assistant dean of the engineering faculty at the Hopkins, addressed an
assembly of the Senior Class at the
Towson High School Tuesday morning. His subject was "The Electric
Shock."

By STANLEY E. BLUMBERG
Question—Is it true that there were
hitch-hikers along "The Road to
Rome" who asked Hannibal for a lift
aboard his elephant?
Answer—Of course not. According
to the newspapers, the only animal
capable of giving a lift is a camel.
Question—But I read that these
hitch-hikers were always seen to hold
their thumbs in an unusually vertical
position. How can you explain that?
Answer—That's easy. That was
merely their way of saying "thumbs
up" on the 1935 Barnstormer portrayal of their favorite boulevard!
Question—Yes, but how could they
look more than 2000 years into the
future to find this out?
Answer—They didnt have to look.
A little bird told them.
Question—What little bird?
Answer—The bird the Romans gave
the Carthaginians! Or is that a
Punic pun?
Question—Tell me, what's happened to this bird since then?
Answer—It has passed into the
hands of a critical theatre-going public, which has employed it upon numerous occasions to vent its displeasure of certain Thespian nightmares.
Question—What an interesting bit
of ornithology. Do you think the
Barnstormers will be the recipient of
one of these birds tomorrow night?
Answer—Certainly not.
They've
got class. And besides, they've already got a bird of their own. You
know, Evelyn Swann.
Question—Swann? Swann? The
name sounds familiar. Is she a capable actress?
Answer—Capable! Why, Swann
takes to acting like a duck takes to
water Get it?
Question—Oh, yes.
Swann and
duck—duck and swan—Swann and
swan—quite syllogistic, eh what?
Answer—You mean sillygistic.
Question—By the by, who is to portray the role of Hannibal in "The
Road to Rome?" He was a great
general, you know.
Answer—Jerry Branower is down
for that part. And speaking of great
generals, there's nobody who can even
touch Jerry. Why, he licks George
Washington every time he stamps a
letter!
Question—But Hannibal is supposed to be able to climb the Alps.
How is Branower going to manage
this?
Answer—Oh, he's a Phi Ep.
Question—What's that got to do
with it?
Answer—He does things backwards. He'll make a molehill out
of the mountain.
Question—According to history,
Hannibal finally met his master in a
certain Fabius Maximus, the Roman
Woodrow Wilson. Who is to represent him?
Answer—Zenas Sears. Te burns
Hannibal up!
Question—You know, women ,a1ways interest me behind the footlights. I hope you won't take this
amiss (oh, heavens, I've made a pun
myself!) but I think the opposite sex
lend a definite angle to the theatre,
don't you?
Answer—You mean a definite
curve.
Question—Are there any other
feminine parts?
Answer—Well, we haven't got Madame X, Sadie Thompson, or Mrs.
Malaprop, but Helen Cadwalader and
Elizabeth Ullman do right well by
our Roman Romeos.
Question—That's great. But tell
me, how is the addience going to understand the actors if they speak in
the Latin of Livy?
Answer—That's just the point,
friend. They're going to speak in
modern dialect.
Question—Would
that be
pig
Latin?
Answer—Skip it, skip it.
Question—Skip what?
Answer—Your next ten questions.

Once again catering to the insistent demands of my intellectual readers, who have been clamoring loudly
for a new issue of the Quad Quip
Qwazy Qwictionary, I present:
Alliance: The kind of den they
put Daniel in.
Circle: A round straight line with
a hole in the middle.
Vacuum: A large empty space
where the Pope lives.
Par: The fellow who pays our tuition.
Stomach: Human organ, just south
of the ribs.
All right, I yield. Dont shoot.
• * *
While on this subject of mixups,
We'll begin with a box, and the plural
is boxes,
But the plural of ox should be oxen,
not oxes.
Then one fowl is a goose, but two are
called geese,
Yet the plural of mouse should never
be meese.
You may find a lone mouse, or a
whole nest of mice,
But the plural of house is houses,
not hice.
If one is a tooth, and a whole set are
teeth,
Why should not the plural of booth
be called beeth?
Then one would be that, and three
would be those,
Yet the plural of hat would never
be hose.

In making these tests, 6336 meaningless syllables
are spoken — while observers record what they hear.
Comparison of sounds actually spoken with those heard,
shows how well the new apparatus reproduces the many
sounds of which speech is composed.
Such thoroughness is typical of Bell System methods.
Years of inventing, improving and testing have led to

HOMEWOOD. BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 10, 1935.

Nine Jays Sent
ToIlliddle States
Championships
Neu, Graziano, Kelly, Clark,
Peppler, Sholtes, Emmert,
Holtzman, Chancellor Go

ExpectTo Show Well
Holtzman And Neu Counted
Last Year; Chancellor Lone
Entry In Weights
Fresh from a decisive triumph over
Catholic University, the Johns Hopkins track team will seek further
laurels this Saturday at the Middle
Atlantic Collegiate Championships.
Nine men will carry the Jay colors
into action and are expected to tally
a considerable number of points for
the Black and Blue.
In 1934 only three Hopkins competitors succeeded in gaining places
and one of these, Jack King, did not
return to school this year. Paul Holtzman and Captain Willard Neu are
the two Jay performers who scored.
Holtzman obtained third position in
the two-mile run, while Neu lost out
by a half inch for first place in the
broiad jump. The former won his
specialty two years ago, and hopes
to repeat tomorrow.
Another strong entrant in the same
event for Hopkins is Leonard Emmert. Emmert has not been defeated
in the two-mile grind during the present campaign, and his time compares
favorably with his prospective opponents.
The Black and Blue possesses a
particularly strong sprint entry. Neu,
who is as proficient in the dashes as
in the broad jump, will run the century, and will be accompanied by
Ted Graziano and Charlie Kelly. The
former also will hurl the javelin,
while Kelly will line up with Gus
Clark, another Jay representative, in
the furlong. Peppler will carry the
Black and Blue colors in the 440, with
Clark doubling up to run the same
event.
Carl Sholtes and Opie Chancellor
complete the list of Hopkins' entrants, the former competing in the
distances and the latter representing
the Jays in the field events. Chancellor possesses the second best performance in the discus among the
teams in the Middle Atlantic Asso-

The Frosh stickmen bowed to a
superior Boys' Latin squad, Wednesday, 7 to 2. Boys' Latin, one of the
outstanding high school lacrosse
teams in the state, displayed too
much power for Frank Dotterweich's
ten.
Hill and Frey made the only tallies
Early in the first
for the Jays.
period, Hill recovered a free ball in
the crease and scored easily. The
second tally was made in the last
period by a pass from Marty Simensky to Frey, who scored.
Due to the muddy field it is hard to
criticize pro or con for both teams.
However, Boys' Latin showed a great
punch around the circle and the Jays'
defense was too slow to check them.
The first half ended with Boys'
Latin leading with a 3-1 score, but
the Frosh were pressing them for a
second tally.
The second half opened with the
ball in the Jays' territory. A quick
series of plays resulted in Williams
shooting his second goal for the day.
The Frosh began riding them but the
Latin School proved too strong and
before the third quarter ended, Spillman scored, giving them a dangerous
lead of 4 points.
Vickers opened the final quarter by
scoring the sixth goal for Boys' Latin.
After this tally the tide changed for
about six minutes. The Jays began
a series of beautiful plays that truly
was a tribute to their good coaching,

Two types of awards for Omicron
Delta Kappa, honorary activities fraternity, were presented at yesterday's
assembly when James Butcher, a
senior, and Clarence Weimer, Mead
Johnson, and Leonard Emmert, juniors were tapped by President T.
Bayard Williams, Jr.; and Dr. John
C. French, second national president,
was given a past president's Key by
William Mofeley Brown, executive
secretary of the national fraternity.
Preceding the announcement of
the new selections by Richard Feise,
Williams outlined the principles upon
which the organization is based. He
stated:
"Most students fail to grasp the
idea that two of our primary requisites are scholarship and character.
Before we consider any case, the individual must have, as the NEWSLETTER put it, 'a respectable general
average.' We will continue to emphasize these two requirements in the
future."
Told Of Hopkins' Part
Mr. Brown told the audience of the
part played by the Hopkins chapter of
0. D. K., the second one established,
having followed Washington and Lee.
He congratulated those who were
just inducted and informed them of
the significance of the honor. Adding
that there was a special award for
past officers, Mr. Brown presented
Dr. French with a gold key.
"Being president of 0. D. K. from
1920-1922," the speaker declared,
"Dr. French was instrumental in the
great progress the organization attained. I am happy to honor such a
past leader of this fraternity."
Dean Berry Comments
When called upon to address the
assembly, Dr. ?French recalled the
early days of the organization and
praised the recent progress which 0.
D. K. has made. He issued a warning
to the Hopkins Chapter not to be too
exclusive in their selection of new
members since the organization has
such an important position on the
campus.
Before the presentation of the 0.
D. K. awards, the freshman class
team which won the basketball championship were given charms.
William McClean, president of the
Student Council, introduced Dean
Edward W. Berry, whom he said
would "give the boys hell" about the
past Soph-Frosh Week.
"I can appreciate the feelings of
youth," Dean Berry stated, "yet I
think this past week which gave the
worst exhibition I've ever seen, went
too far. Such demonstrations do Hopkins no end of harm. The present
freshmen who will be sophomores
next year should bear this past experience in mind and take the lead
next year in toning down such activities."
After the regular assembly, five
freshmein Were nominated for the
Student Council. They were:
JAMES LYLE
EVERETT GAUNT
DONALD EMERSON
MARTIN SIMENSKY
ROBERT STEVENS
Primaries will be today and general elections on Monday.

Kouwenhoven Speaks
Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven, professor of electrical engineering and
assistant dean of the engineering faculty at the Hopkins, addressed an
assembly of the Senior Class at the
Towson High School Tuesday morning. His subject was "The Electric
Shock."

By STANLEY E. BLUMBERG
Question—Is it true that there were
hitch-hikers along "The Road to
Rome" who asked Hannibal for a lift
aboard his elephant?
Answer—Of course not. According
to the newspapers, the only animal
capable of giving a lift is a camel.
Question—But I read that these
hitch-hikers were always seen to hold
their thumbs in an unusually vertical
position. How can you explain that?
Answer—That's easy. That was
merely their way of saying "thumbs
up" on the 1935 Barnstormer portrayal of their favorite boulevard!
Question—Yes, but how could they
look more than 2000 years into the
future to find this out?
Answer—They didnt have to look.
A little bird told them.
Question—What little bird?
Answer—The bird the Romans gave
the Carthaginians! Or is that a
Punic pun?
Question—Tell me, what's happened to this bird since then?
Answer—It has passed into the
hands of a critical theatre-going public, which has employed it upon numerous occasions to vent its displeasure of certain Thespian nightmares.
Question—What an interesting bit
of ornithology. Do you think the
Barnstormers will be the recipient of
one of these birds tomorrow night?
Answer—Certainly not.
They've
got class. And besides, they've already got a bird of their own. You
know, Evelyn Swann.
Question—Swann? Swann? The
name sounds familiar. Is she a capable actress?
Answer—Capable! Why, Swann
takes to acting like a duck takes to
water Get it?
Question—Oh, yes.
Swann and
duck—duck and swan—Swann and
swan—quite syllogistic, eh what?
Answer—You mean sillygistic.
Question—By the by, who is to portray the role of Hannibal in "The
Road to Rome?" He was a great
general, you know.
Answer—Jerry Branower is down
for that part. And speaking of great
generals, there's nobody who can even
touch Jerry. Why, he licks George
Washington every time he stamps a
letter!
Question—But Hannibal is supposed to be able to climb the Alps.
How is Branower going to manage
this?
Answer—Oh, he's a Phi Ep.
Question—What's that got to do
with it?
Answer—He does things backwards. He'll make a molehill out
of the mountain.
Question—According to history,
Hannibal finally met his master in a
certain Fabius Maximus, the Roman
Woodrow Wilson. Who is to represent him?
Answer—Zenas Sears. Te burns
Hannibal up!
Question—You know, women ,a1ways interest me behind the footlights. I hope you won't take this
amiss (oh, heavens, I've made a pun
myself!) but I think the opposite sex
lend a definite angle to the theatre,
don't you?
Answer—You mean a definite
curve.
Question—Are there any other
feminine parts?
Answer—Well, we haven't got Madame X, Sadie Thompson, or Mrs.
Malaprop, but Helen Cadwalader and
Elizabeth Ullman do right well by
our Roman Romeos.
Question—That's great. But tell
me, how is the addience going to understand the actors if they speak in
the Latin of Livy?
Answer—That's just the point,
friend. They're going to speak in
modern dialect.
Question—Would
that be
pig
Latin?
Answer—Skip it, skip it.
Question—Skip what?
Answer—Your next ten questions.

While on this subject of mixups,
We'll begin with a box, and the plural
is boxes,
But the plural of ox should be oxen,
not oxes.
Then one fowl is a goose, but two are
called geese,
Yet the plural of mouse should never
be meese.
You may find a lone mouse, or a
whole nest of mice,
But the plural of house is houses,
not hice.
If one is a tooth, and a whole set are
teeth,
Why should not the plural of booth
be called beeth?
Then one would be that, and three
would be those,
Yet the plural of hat would never
be hose.

This young lady records the meaningless syllables spoken by the man.
ND,"How does kib like that?" Such questions sound
senseless — yet they play an important part in
making articulation tests on new types of telephone
apparatus at Bell Telephone Laboratories.
In making these tests, 6336 meaningless syllables
are spoken — while observers record what they hear.
Comparison of sounds actually spoken with those heard,
shows how well the new apparatus reproduces the many
sounds of which speech is composed.
Such thoroughness is typical of Bell System methods.
Years of inventing, improving and testing have led to
the apparatus which transmits your words so clearly.

HOMEWOOD. BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 10, 1935.

Nine Jays Sent
ToIlliddle States
Championships
Neu, Graziano, Kelly, Clark,
Peppler, Sholtes, Emmert,
Holtzman, Chancellor Go

ExpectTo Show Well
Holtzman And Neu Counted
Last Year; Chancellor Lone
Entry In Weights
Fresh from a decisive triumph over
Catholic University, the Johns Hopkins track team will seek further
laurels this Saturday at the Middle
Atlantic Collegiate Championships.
Nine men will carry the Jay colors
into action and are expected to tally
a considerable number of points for
the Black and Blue.
In 1934 only three Hopkins competitors succeeded in gaining places
and one of these, Jack King, did not
return to school this year. Paul Holtzman and Captain Willard Neu are
the two Jay performers who scored.
Holtzman obtained third position in
the two-mile run, while Neu lost out
by a half inch for first place in the
broiad jump. The former won his
specialty two years ago, and hopes
to repeat tomorrow.
Another strong entrant in the same
event for Hopkins is Leonard Emmert. Emmert has not been defeated
in the two-mile grind during the present campaign, and his time compares
favorably with his prospective opponents.
The Black and Blue possesses a
particularly strong sprint entry. Neu,
who is as proficient in the dashes as
in the broad jump, will run the century, and will be accompanied by
Ted Graziano and Charlie Kelly. The
former also will hurl the javelin,
while Kelly will line up with Gus
Clark, another Jay representative, in
the furlong. Peppler will carry the
Black and Blue colors in the 440, with
Clark doubling up to run the same
event.
Carl Sholtes and Opie Chancellor
complete the list of Hopkins' entrants, the former competing in the
distances and the latter representing
the Jays in the field events. Chancellor possesses the second best performance in the discus among the
teams in the Middle Atlantic Asso-

The Frosh stickmen bowed to a
superior Boys' Latin squad, Wednesday, 7 to 2. Boys' Latin, one of the
outstanding high school lacrosse
teams in the state, displayed too
much power for Frank Dotterweich's
ten.
Hill and Frey made the only tallies
Early in the first
for the Jays.
period, Hill recovered a free ball in
the crease and scored easily. The
second tally was made in the last
period by a pass from Marty Simensky to Frey, who scored.
Due to the muddy field it is hard to
criticize pro or con for both teams.
However, Boys' Latin showed a great
punch around the circle and the Jays'
defense was too slow to check them.
The first half ended with Boys'
Latin leading with a 3-1 score, but
the Frosh were pressing them for a
second tally.
The second half opened with the
ball in the Jays' territory. A quick
series of plays resulted in Williams
shooting his second goal for the day.
